description: Those looking to complete the initial Mac Integration Basics exam to obtain the Apple Certified Associates (ACA) Certification will find in this course an overview of the process in achieving the certification and details about the exam required to pass in order to receive the certification. One will learn in this course how to use Mac OS in a corporate/ enterprise environment, integrate it with other systems, and learn how to perform actions such as sharing files, printers, and other things that run between multiple systems running Mac OS.
name: Mac Integration Basics 10.9
subtitle: Mavericks 10.9

episodes.description: The Apple Certified Associate (ACA) certification is an entry level certification that shows one has a basic understanding of how to use Mac OS in a corporate or enterprise environment and can integrate it with other systems. The ACA certification can be achieved in two versions through either Mac Integration Basics or Mac Management Basics and is an excellent starting point for people working with Macintosh systems in a networked environment. Viewers will hear an overview about the knowledge one needs to attain the ACA certification, about the Mac Integration Basics Exam and the exam objectives of topics one should know for the exam.

none of which are the full name.

691
00:36:09,750 --> 00:36:13,310
I couldn't type in Teacher1 as words,
like this.

692
00:36:13,310 --> 00:36:15,670
It's got to be one of these three formats.

693
00:36:15,670 --> 00:36:20,240
So usernames are a little less flexible
inside of active directory, and

694
00:36:20,240 --> 00:36:23,330
it's because they have
to make allowance for

695
00:36:23,330 --> 00:36:25,980
having multiple users with the same name,
right?

696
00:36:25,980 --> 00:36:29,100
I might have two users named John Doe.

697
00:36:29,100 --> 00:36:32,350
Well, the open directory doesn't
account for that very well.

698
00:36:33,570 --> 00:36:35,500
You know I hate to make it sound negative.

699
00:36:35,500 --> 00:36:37,030
Open directory is very powerful.

700
00:36:37,030 --> 00:36:38,500
It can do a lot of stuff.

701
00:36:38,500 --> 00:36:42,490
The native way, the way that it's set
up by default doesn't account for

702
00:36:42,490 --> 00:36:44,150
two people with the same name very well.

703
00:36:44,150 --> 00:36:45,900
So that's where we start
to have the problems.

704
00:36:45,900 --> 00:36:48,884
And you can tweak it and
make it handle that better if you want.

705
00:36:48,884 --> 00:36:52,160
But active directory handles it
like that from the very beginning.

706
00:36:52,160 --> 00:36:55,690
It's part of the reason why active
directory is so complex to set up.

707
00:36:55,690 --> 00:36:56,817
Because it's already planning for

708
00:36:56,817 --> 00:36:58,889
these eventualities right from
the very beginning, all right.

709
00:37:00,030 --> 00:37:03,410
So, three different usernames,
that's all the same person.

710
00:37:03,410 --> 00:37:07,250
If I log in as any of those three,
we'll see the same information, and

711
00:37:07,250 --> 00:37:08,500
we could test that.

712
00:37:08,500 --> 00:37:11,600
Probably extremely boring,
but we could test that out

713
00:37:11,600 --> 00:37:15,460
if we wanted to by changing the wallpaper,
or something that to see each one.

714
00:37:15,460 --> 00:37:18,407
But if I wanna log in
here as lab/ Teacher1.

715
00:37:20,100 --> 00:37:24,100
That'll be that same account and
I can get logged in and work with my data.

716
00:37:24,100 --> 00:37:26,740
It's not a new, in fact,
see how it automatically opened this

717
00:37:26,740 --> 00:37:30,190
folder that I had open before
cuz it's still my same account.

718
00:37:30,190 --> 00:37:33,550
If I go into system preferences and users.

719
00:37:33,550 --> 00:37:36,220
I'll see there's only one teacher one,
it didn't add a second one.

720
00:37:36,220 --> 00:37:36,880
It's the same account.

721
00:37:38,792 --> 00:37:41,880
All right, so
that's the process right there for

722
00:37:41,880 --> 00:37:45,410
binding to open directory and
binding to active directory.

723
00:37:45,410 --> 00:37:50,350
Those are the two supported directory
services that are out there on your Macs.

724
00:37:50,350 --> 00:37:53,790
Now there are other directory services
available, but these are the two that

725
00:37:53,790 --> 00:37:57,020
Apple supports out of the box and
honestly they're probably the two best.

726
00:37:57,020 --> 00:38:00,220
Active directory being the most common,
open directory being the one that's

727
00:38:00,220 --> 00:38:04,190
directly Apple supported and
just super stable and easy to deploy.

728
00:38:04,190 --> 00:38:05,210
Lots of benefits there, so.

729
00:38:07,100 --> 00:38:10,380
All right, well that's about all
we've got for network accounts.

730
00:38:10,380 --> 00:38:13,080
In the next show we're going to
be tackling file sharing, and

731
00:38:13,080 --> 00:38:16,530
with file sharing we're gonna talk
about how to provide network access,

732
00:38:16,530 --> 00:38:19,460
and that's where our network accounts
are really gonna come in handy too.

733
00:38:19,460 --> 00:38:22,270
So we'll get a chance to see
that in our next episodes, so

734
00:38:22,270 --> 00:38:24,050
make sure you stay tuned for that.

735
00:38:24,050 --> 00:38:28,080
In the meantime, if you have any questions
on what we covered in this show,

736
00:38:28,080 --> 00:38:33,350
make sure, if it's live, live during the
show you can go to http://itpro.tv/live,

737
00:38:33,350 --> 00:38:35,580
you'll see the chat box
right beneath the video.

738
00:38:35,580 --> 00:38:37,280
But if you're watching this recorded,

739
00:38:37,280 --> 00:38:40,130
make sure you take advantage
of our Q&A section.

740
00:38:40,130 --> 00:38:43,647
At the top of every page of my itpro.tv
you'll see a link that says Q&A.

741
00:38:43,647 --> 00:38:46,660
It'll take you into the forms and
you can post your questions there.

742
00:38:46,660 --> 00:38:47,650
We monitor and answer.

743
00:38:47,650 --> 00:38:49,940
We wanna make sure you guys get
the information you need so

744
00:38:49,940 --> 00:38:51,630
you can be successful on that exam.

745
00:38:51,630 --> 00:38:54,880
So definitely take advantage of
that resource, it's there for you.

746
00:38:54,880 --> 00:38:57,080
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

747
00:38:57,080 --> 00:38:59,408
Signing off for itpro.tv, I Don Pezet.

748
00:38:59,408 --> 00:39:01,334
And I'll see you next time.

episodes.description: Being able to share information between systems is an important step in setting up a Mac to work in a network environment. Viewers will hear about the different methods for file sharing that are supported and see demonstrations for Mac-to-Mac and Mac-to-Windows file sharing.
episodes.title: File Sharing
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,503 --> 00:00:34,129
All right.

3
00:00:34,129 --> 00:00:36,171
Good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening.

4
00:00:36,171 --> 00:00:41,047
And, welcome back to another episode of
ITProTV, I am your slightly uncoordinated

5
00:00:41,047 --> 00:00:45,447
host Don Pezet, back with another
episode of Apple Certified Associates,

6
00:00:45,447 --> 00:00:49,150
more specifically the Mac
integration basics show.

7
00:00:49,150 --> 00:00:50,700
So this is episode number 2, and

8
00:00:50,700 --> 00:00:53,970
we're going to be diving in,
or episode number 3?

9
00:00:53,970 --> 00:00:55,440
I don't know.
Whatever episode number it is.

10
00:00:55,440 --> 00:01:00,120
We're going t o be diving into file
sharing, so how can we share information

11
00:01:00,120 --> 00:01:04,570
that's on one Mac with the other Macs on
our network, or maybe not even a Mac.

12
00:01:04,570 --> 00:01:07,580
Maybe we have a Unix system or a Windows
system or something like that, and

13
00:01:07,580 --> 00:01:10,430
we want to share data
between the two systems.

14
00:01:10,430 --> 00:01:11,070
All right.

15
00:01:11,070 --> 00:01:15,360
Well, Mac OS has a full suite
of connectivity protocols, so

16
00:01:15,360 --> 00:01:17,260
we actually have a lot of power.

17
00:01:17,260 --> 00:01:18,640
Just right here, ready to do.

18
00:01:18,640 --> 00:01:21,140
So, let's take a look at that.

19
00:01:21,140 --> 00:01:23,650
Now, I want to start out just
kind of covering the different

20
00:01:23,650 --> 00:01:27,950
ways that are supported, because you know
that you can share content between Macs.

21
00:01:27,950 --> 00:01:28,940
That makes sense.

22
00:01:28,940 --> 00:01:32,340
But, you can also share between Mac and
Windows, or Mac and Linux.

23
00:01:32,340 --> 00:01:34,740
So, you do have a lot of flexibility.

24
00:01:34,740 --> 00:01:40,130
That flexibility comes from all of the
different protocols that Mac OS supports.

25
00:01:40,130 --> 00:01:43,820
So, let's take a look
at all those protocols.

26
00:01:43,820 --> 00:01:45,290
Let me just move some of stuff off here.

27
00:01:45,290 --> 00:01:46,550
Here we go.

28
00:01:46,550 --> 00:01:49,130
Mac OS right out of the box,
have native support for

29
00:01:49,130 --> 00:01:52,430
six different file sharing protocols,
all right?

30
00:01:52,430 --> 00:01:53,960
Some of these are very popular,

31
00:01:53,960 --> 00:01:57,560
ones you'll use all the time, others
are ones that you'll use very rarely.

32
00:01:57,560 --> 00:02:00,230
So let me just run down the list and
kind of show you.

33
00:02:00,230 --> 00:02:03,690
The first one is AFP,
the Apple file protocol and of course

34
00:02:03,690 --> 00:02:07,330
it makes sense we're going to support
that one because it's an Apple product.

35
00:02:07,330 --> 00:02:11,360
So when you're sharing data
between two Macs You're using AFP.

36
00:02:12,390 --> 00:02:17,350
But if you're going from Mac to Windows,
well, Windows doesn't support AFP.

37
00:02:17,350 --> 00:02:23,345
Windows uses a file sharing protocol
called server message block, or SMB.

38
00:02:23,345 --> 00:02:24,075
All right.

39
00:02:24,075 --> 00:02:27,005
You'll here some people on
the internet call it SAMBA.

40
00:02:27,005 --> 00:02:30,815
SAMBA's actually an open source
implementation of SMB, so

41
00:02:30,815 --> 00:02:33,015
SAMBA is a program, not the protocol.

42
00:02:33,015 --> 00:02:34,400
The protocol itself is SMB.

43
00:02:34,400 --> 00:02:37,262
And server message block is it's private.

44
00:02:37,262 --> 00:02:41,172
It was developed originally by Intel,
but it's now owned by Microsoft, and

45
00:02:41,172 --> 00:02:43,032
it's a Microsoft thing.

46
00:02:43,032 --> 00:02:46,812
So if somebody wants to support SMB,
they have to license it, and

47
00:02:46,812 --> 00:02:47,642
that's what Apple did.

48
00:02:47,642 --> 00:02:49,930
Apple reached out to Microsoft and
bought a license so

49
00:02:49,930 --> 00:02:52,940
that we could integrate with those
Windows machines, all right?

50
00:02:52,940 --> 00:02:57,660
Now, SMB is the name for
the proprietary software.

51
00:02:57,660 --> 00:03:03,510
Microsoft has open sourced some of it and
so the open source freely available one

52
00:03:03,510 --> 00:03:08,550
is called CIFTS or
common internet file system, all right?.

53
00:03:08,550 --> 00:03:11,390
SNB and
CIFTS are obviously the same thing.

54
00:03:11,390 --> 00:03:14,010
They're fully compatible
with each other and so,

55
00:03:14,010 --> 00:03:16,380
you can use the names interchangeably.

56
00:03:16,380 --> 00:03:20,310
Just remember that CIFTS is like
the open standard that anyone can run

57
00:03:20,310 --> 00:03:21,630
without licensing.

58
00:03:21,630 --> 00:03:23,960
SMB is the one that
does require licensing.

59
00:03:23,960 --> 00:03:27,840
SMB has some extra security features
that are not included in SIFS, but

60
00:03:27,840 --> 00:03:30,330
functionality wise the two
are completely compatible.

61
00:03:31,380 --> 00:03:34,530
So when we connect to one
of these file shares,

62
00:03:34,530 --> 00:03:37,610
whether it's SMB of SIFS,
we actually connect the same way.

63
00:03:37,610 --> 00:03:43,774
See here with AFP, when we connect
to a server, we specify afp://,

64
00:03:43,774 --> 00:03:49,460
kind of like a web address,
http://, here it's afp://.

65
00:03:49,460 --> 00:03:51,140
Followed by the server name and

66
00:03:51,140 --> 00:03:53,980
then the folder name that we're
connecting to, all right?

67
00:03:53,980 --> 00:03:58,970
With CIFS and SMB,
in both scenarios we say smb:// whatever.

68
00:04:00,980 --> 00:04:09,420
Now, Mac OS, the user interface, all the
visual elements of it, that's 100% Apple.

69
00:04:09,420 --> 00:04:14,610
But under the hood, it's running BSD,
which is a Unix based operating system.

70
00:04:14,610 --> 00:04:15,700
And in the Unix world,

71
00:04:15,700 --> 00:04:20,390
the most common file sharing system
is NFS, the Network File System.

72
00:04:20,390 --> 00:04:22,770
And so, we have NSF support.

73
00:04:22,770 --> 00:04:23,490
And again,

74
00:04:23,490 --> 00:04:27,530
connect to that would just be NSF://
followed by the server and folder name.

75
00:04:28,870 --> 00:04:33,390
There are a few less common
ones supported, like webdav.

76
00:04:33,390 --> 00:04:37,090
Webdav is web distributed authoring and
versioning.

77
00:04:37,090 --> 00:04:42,160
It's a file protocol that actually uses
web standards, or HTTP, to connect.

78
00:04:42,160 --> 00:04:46,180
It's not very popular because there's been
some high visibility security flaws and

79
00:04:46,180 --> 00:04:47,380
web dab over the years.

80
00:04:47,380 --> 00:04:51,495
So, a lot of network admins and
people like me really hate to

81
00:04:51,495 --> 00:04:55,785
implement it if they can avoid it,
so it's not popular as the others.

82
00:04:55,785 --> 00:04:59,935
And then there's good old FTP,
the File Transfer Protocol.

83
00:04:59,935 --> 00:05:04,585
FTP is a super easy way to transfer
files between any system, Windows,

84
00:05:04,585 --> 00:05:09,465
Linux, Mac, whatever, but it does
everything in a very nonsecure way.

85
00:05:09,465 --> 00:05:12,195
You have usernames and passwords,
but they're sent in plain

86
00:05:12,195 --> 00:05:15,700
text over the network, so
it's a securities professionals nightmare.

87
00:05:15,700 --> 00:05:17,490
But we do have support for that one too.

88
00:05:17,490 --> 00:05:21,800
FTP, colon, slash, slash,
followed by server name and folder name.

89
00:05:21,800 --> 00:05:24,860
Support for
all of these protocols is native.

90
00:05:24,860 --> 00:05:25,630
It's cooked in.

91
00:05:25,630 --> 00:05:28,710
It's built right in to
the operating system.

92
00:05:28,710 --> 00:05:31,780
You might have other systems
that you want to connect to.

93
00:05:31,780 --> 00:05:34,060
Well, just because it's not native
doesn't mean you can't do it.

94
00:05:34,060 --> 00:05:36,720
There's plenty of third part software
that's out there that you can use.

95
00:05:36,720 --> 00:05:39,310
In fact, I use here on my desktop.

96
00:05:39,310 --> 00:05:40,380
Let's see which one of these icons.

97
00:05:40,380 --> 00:05:41,260
This one.

98
00:05:41,260 --> 00:05:45,250
I use a program called Expand Drive, and
that lets me connect to Amazon S3 and

99
00:05:45,250 --> 00:05:49,840
Google Drive and
other file systems that are out there and

100
00:05:49,840 --> 00:05:52,220
mount them as folders or
drives on my system.

101
00:05:52,220 --> 00:05:56,300
So you can always expand
the functionality of MacOS if you want.

102
00:05:56,300 --> 00:05:59,930
But native, built right in here,
you've got a lot of functionality.

103
00:06:01,012 --> 00:06:05,200
All right, so let's say that we
want to share some data, and

104
00:06:05,200 --> 00:06:06,890
let's just do between Macs to start.

105
00:06:06,890 --> 00:06:09,180
We'll do Windows later.

106
00:06:09,180 --> 00:06:13,880
So if I want to share data between
Macs I need to pick which Mac

107
00:06:13,880 --> 00:06:18,130
has the files I want to share, so
somebody is holding onto that data, and

108
00:06:18,130 --> 00:06:20,190
that might be a file server.

109
00:06:20,190 --> 00:06:24,010
I might actually have a Mac that's
dedicated to be my file server, or

110
00:06:24,010 --> 00:06:26,150
it might just be somebody's work station.

111
00:06:26,150 --> 00:06:29,810
So let's go at it from the perspective
of just a regular Joe shmoe user.

112
00:06:29,810 --> 00:06:34,900
So on this client right here,
I am just a regular Joe Schmo user.

113
00:06:34,900 --> 00:06:35,960
So I'm just Don Pizet.

114
00:06:35,960 --> 00:06:37,720
I'm logged in.

115
00:06:37,720 --> 00:06:40,520
I want to share some data,
some data that I have.

116
00:06:40,520 --> 00:06:44,790
Well the easiest way to do it
is to use personal file sharing.

117
00:06:44,790 --> 00:06:48,030
Personal file sharing is one
of the most simple methods.

118
00:06:48,030 --> 00:06:52,390
Every user has a folder that's a part
of their home directory called

119
00:06:52,390 --> 00:06:54,030
Public files, all right?

120
00:06:54,030 --> 00:06:56,970
And this is where we can put files,
and quickly share them out so

121
00:06:56,970 --> 00:06:58,820
other people can access them.

122
00:06:58,820 --> 00:07:03,330
If you've never seen it, you can just
go up to your Go menu in the Finder and

123
00:07:03,330 --> 00:07:06,950
choose to go into your Home directory,
right here.

124
00:07:06,950 --> 00:07:11,523
So I'm going to go Home, and
in my Home Directory I see my Desktop,

125
00:07:11,523 --> 00:07:14,230
my Documents, my Downloads.

126
00:07:14,230 --> 00:07:16,840
And this folder right here, public.

127
00:07:16,840 --> 00:07:17,570
All right?

128
00:07:17,570 --> 00:07:20,070
Now, when I go into public,
there's not much in there by default.

129
00:07:20,070 --> 00:07:22,210
Looks like I've got my drop box.

130
00:07:22,210 --> 00:07:26,930
But, and that's not Dropbox the website,
it's drop box as in, this is

131
00:07:26,930 --> 00:07:30,500
a folder people will be able to put things
in but not actually be able to get at.

132
00:07:30,500 --> 00:07:32,290
We'll talk about that later.

133
00:07:32,290 --> 00:07:34,150
But basically I could
start to put files and

134
00:07:34,150 --> 00:07:38,820
folders in here and
give other people access to them, right?

135
00:07:38,820 --> 00:07:45,320
So, you know, I could have, you know,
maybe, I'll create a public music folder.

136
00:07:45,320 --> 00:07:46,860
And so I can put some MP3s in there and

137
00:07:46,860 --> 00:07:48,086
other people can browse in and
access them.

138
00:07:49,490 --> 00:07:52,300
Well just having the folder is not enough.

139
00:07:52,300 --> 00:07:54,106
I actually need to turn on file sharing.

140
00:07:54,106 --> 00:07:56,972
And file sharing is not
turned on by default.

141
00:07:56,972 --> 00:08:01,163
So I would need to go up here
into my system preferences.

142
00:08:01,163 --> 00:08:04,940
And go into the sharing system preference.

143
00:08:04,940 --> 00:08:07,440
And from here you'll see a bunch of
different things that we can share.

144
00:08:07,440 --> 00:08:09,660
The one I wantt is file sharing.

145
00:08:09,660 --> 00:08:12,340
And see how it's not checked by default?

146
00:08:12,340 --> 00:08:13,890
Well I'm not going to check it just yet.

147
00:08:13,890 --> 00:08:16,550
Because I want to point out
some of these defaults.

148
00:08:16,550 --> 00:08:20,530
Notice that when I click on file
sharing I can see my shared files.

149
00:08:20,530 --> 00:08:25,790
And by default I've got Don Pezet's
public folder, help desk's public folder.

150
00:08:25,790 --> 00:08:29,570
I have two user accounts on this machine,
Don Pezet and help desk.

151
00:08:29,570 --> 00:08:31,740
If I had five I'd see all five of them.

152
00:08:31,740 --> 00:08:36,320
When we turn file sharing on the default
is to enable it for our public folders,

153
00:08:36,320 --> 00:08:38,552
that's the personal file sharing.

154
00:08:38,552 --> 00:08:43,290
All right, well when we turn that on
If you look at the permissions that

155
00:08:43,290 --> 00:08:45,630
are assigned and,
apparently I can't resize that window.

156
00:08:45,630 --> 00:08:47,380
All right well, when we turn it on,

157
00:08:47,380 --> 00:08:50,950
if you look at the permissions that
are being assigned, Don Pezet,

158
00:08:50,950 --> 00:08:54,660
on the Don Pezet folder here I'll have
read and write, I can do whatever I want.

159
00:08:54,660 --> 00:08:57,690
But everyone else will have read only.

160
00:08:57,690 --> 00:08:59,580
So when you turn on file sharing,

161
00:08:59,580 --> 00:09:02,260
all you have to do is come in here and
check this little box.

162
00:09:02,260 --> 00:09:07,610
And automatically,
your public folder will be shared out, and

163
00:09:07,610 --> 00:09:12,870
everyone can access it, and read, they can
read the data, they can see your files.

164
00:09:12,870 --> 00:09:13,840
They can't delete them,

165
00:09:13,840 --> 00:09:18,050
they can't change them,
they can just see the files, all right?

166
00:09:18,050 --> 00:09:19,930
You on the other hand,
you can do whatever you want.

167

You get read, and write,

00:34:03,300 --> 00:34:06,390
When you choose your permissions,
Jason can we bring this up?

00:34:06,390 --> 00:34:07,680
My notes?

00:34:11,317 --> 00:34:15,780

the most common ones are these two

639
00:34:15,780 --> 00:34:20,020
in the middle, read and write, and
read only, those two guys, all right?

640
00:34:20,020 --> 00:34:21,620
Read and write just like the name implies.

641
00:34:21,620 --> 00:34:24,380
That means that someone can view
the data that's in there, and

642
00:34:24,380 --> 00:34:26,510
they can write changes to it.

643
00:34:26,510 --> 00:34:28,420
Read only means they
can just see the data.

644
00:34:28,420 --> 00:34:30,440
So those are the two that we normally use.

645
00:34:30,440 --> 00:34:34,140
But there were two others:
write only drop box.

646
00:34:34,140 --> 00:34:36,400
This is a really neat one, all right.

647
00:34:36,400 --> 00:34:39,260

we have a drop box folder by default, and

648
00:34:39,260 --> 00:34:40,970

649
00:34:40,970 --> 00:34:44,660
With drop box, somebody can write data.

650
00:34:44,660 --> 00:34:45,840
But not read.

651
00:34:45,840 --> 00:34:47,280
And that sounds really weird.

652
00:34:47,280 --> 00:34:50,470
Why would I want somebody to be able to
make changes but not be able to read?

653
00:34:50,470 --> 00:34:54,210
And the answer is if we want somebody
to be able to drop off something,

654
00:34:54,210 --> 00:34:56,260
a lot of schools make use of this.

655
00:34:56,260 --> 00:34:58,290
They tell their students, all right,
you've got a homework assignment.

656
00:34:58,290 --> 00:34:59,740
You've got to write a paper and

657
00:34:59,740 --> 00:35:02,960
when you're done You've got to
put it in the drop box, right?

658
00:35:02,960 --> 00:35:06,460
And once they throw it in there,
they can't see what's in there.

659
00:35:06,460 --> 00:35:08,010
They can't see the other students' work.

660
00:35:08,010 --> 00:35:10,430
They can't just go and
grab somebody else's work.

661
00:35:10,430 --> 00:35:13,670
And, once they've dropped it in there,
they can't take it back.

662
00:35:13,670 --> 00:35:16,950
So, if they drop it in there and change
their mind about something, too late.

663
00:35:16,950 --> 00:35:21,154
Now they'll have to drop in another one,
and we can look at the time stamps to say

664
00:35:21,154 --> 00:35:25,300
"Oh, they've submitted a change after the
deadline, or something of that nature." So

665
00:35:25,300 --> 00:35:28,610
that drop box feature's really
useful in that type of environment,

666
00:35:28,610 --> 00:35:29,970
schools use it a lot.

667
00:35:29,970 --> 00:35:33,080
In businesses you don't see it as much,
but it can be useful.

668
00:35:33,080 --> 00:35:36,030
All right, so
that's what the write only drop box is.

669
00:35:36,030 --> 00:35:40,440
And then no access, no access we
only see the everyone account, and

670
00:35:40,440 --> 00:35:43,810

671
00:35:43,810 --> 00:35:46,640

00:35:46,640 --> 00:35:49,670

00:35:53,360 --> 00:35:54,750

00:35:54,750 --> 00:35:58,340
groups into the list that
overrides the everyone setting.

00:35:58,340 --> 00:35:59,800

00:36:01,640 --> 00:36:02,410
All right.

Everyone else.

episodes.description: Backing up and managing data is important especially when transferring data to new systems and when wanting to avoid data loss in the event of a hard drive failure or a similar instance. Viewers will hear about moving system information over from Windows to Mac through the Migration Assistant tool, other ways Apple recommends moving data between systems, and the backup process through Time Machine.

00:20:03,720 --> 00:20:04,370

00:20:04,370 --> 00:20:09,360

00:20:09,360 --> 00:20:11,160

00:20:11,160 --> 00:20:12,570
So if you get an Apple machine,

00:20:19,080 --> 00:20:20,440

00:20:21,890 --> 00:20:26,320

works on Windows, works on Mac.

00:20:26,320 --> 00:20:29,760
So you can take an external drive
like this, plug it into your PC,

00:20:29,760 --> 00:20:35,860

386
00:20:35,860 --> 00:20:38,050
Some of the things to worry
about with this method.

387
00:20:38,050 --> 00:20:40,920
First off, it's up to you to make

388
00:20:40,920 --> 00:20:47,220
Second, you've got to use a file system
that's compatible between the two OS's.

389
00:20:47,220 --> 00:20:49,260
If I connect this to a Windows machine and

390
00:20:49,260 --> 00:20:53,800

it's going to format it as NTFS.

391
00:20:53,800 --> 00:20:57,380
That's the Windows NT file
system that Microsoft uses.

392
00:20:57,380 --> 00:21:03,080
Mac OS has support for
NTFS, but read-only.

393
00:21:03,080 --> 00:21:07,210
So your Mac can read NTFS,
but it can't write to it.

394
00:21:07,210 --> 00:21:10,310
So if you're just transferring data
from Windows to Mac, that's fine.

395
00:21:10,310 --> 00:21:14,340
You can format this NTFS, copy your
data to it, throw it on your Mac, and

396
00:21:14,340 --> 00:21:16,766
copy it in to your Mac, all right?

397
00:21:16,766 --> 00:21:21,030
But if you want to move data back and
forth, between a Windows and

398
00:21:21,030 --> 00:21:25,610
a Mac machine, this won't work, because
your Mac won't be able to write to it.

399
00:21:25,610 --> 00:21:29,820
So we need to format it in a way
that's compatible with both systems.

400
00:21:29,820 --> 00:21:34,606
Well, you'll see a lot of websites, and
I think they even mention it in the book

401
00:21:34,606 --> 00:21:39,552
somewhere, that you can format the hard
drive with FAT, File Allocation Table.

402
00:21:39,552 --> 00:21:45,660
The problem with FAT is it doesn't
support files over two gigabytes in size.

403
00:21:45,660 --> 00:21:47,450
And that used to not be a big deal, but

404
00:21:47,450 --> 00:21:52,090
today, a lot of us deal with files
over two gigs on a regular basis.

405
00:21:52,090 --> 00:21:58,460
I have ISOs, DVD images that are over
two gigs, videos, our episodes.

406
00:21:58,460 --> 00:22:02,060
When we film an episode like this, the
originals are way over two gigs in size.

407
00:22:02,060 --> 00:22:04,930
So that's definitely something
that's gonna be a problem.

408
00:22:04,930 --> 00:22:07,950
So there's got to be a better
middle ground, and there is.

409
00:22:07,950 --> 00:22:11,978
There's a file system called exFAT,
E-X-FAT.

410
00:22:11,978 --> 00:22:15,360
It's Extended File Allocation Table.

411
00:22:15,360 --> 00:22:18,530
And what it is,
is it's still really based on FAT, but

412
00:22:18,530 --> 00:22:21,620
it supports files over 2 gigs in size.

413
00:22:21,620 --> 00:22:23,860
And if you format your drive with exFAT,

414
00:22:23,860 --> 00:22:25,840
you'll be able to move it
between the two systems.

00:23:53,255 --> 00:23:56,638

00:24:05,599 --> 00:24:06,444

00:24:06,444 --> 00:24:08,540

00:24:08,540 --> 00:24:13,700

00:24:13,700 --> 00:24:16,050

00:24:16,050 --> 00:24:21,250

00:24:21,250 --> 00:24:22,600

00:24:22,600 --> 00:24:24,177
So when you are using exFAT,

00:24:24,177 --> 00:24:28,265
make sure you properly eject the drive
when you're not using it, right.

00:24:28,265 --> 00:24:32,149
So you need to make that
anytime you are not using it,

454
00:24:32,149 --> 00:24:36,848
properly drag over it and eject it or
can use the finder to do it.

00:24:36,848 --> 00:24:40,350
Use your eject button any time you
are going to disconnect that drive.

456
00:24:40,350 --> 00:24:42,520
So that it doesn't get corrupted.

00:24:42,520 --> 00:24:47,473

00:24:53,090 --> 00:24:57,650

00:24:57,650 --> 00:24:59,780

00:24:59,780 --> 00:25:03,280

00:25:03,280 --> 00:25:04,860

00:25:04,860 --> 00:25:08,370
First off, most mail servers

00:25:08,370 --> 00:25:11,650

00:25:11,650 --> 00:25:15,290

00:25:15,290 --> 00:25:18,360

00:25:18,360 --> 00:25:21,580
The other problem is email

00:25:21,580 --> 00:25:24,810
so when you email your data,

471
00:25:24,810 --> 00:25:27,680
somebody might be able to

00:25:27,680 --> 00:25:29,470
So we wanna be careful with those options.

00:25:29,470 --> 00:25:31,460
They're not the most reliable.

00:25:31,460 --> 00:25:35,200
Right?
Just be careful with that one.

00:26:45,140 --> 00:26:48,900
Well several years ago Apple

00:26:48,900 --> 00:26:52,810

00:26:52,810 --> 00:26:57,760
awesome features inside of Mac OS

00:26:57,760 --> 00:27:01,800

00:27:01,800 --> 00:27:03,181

00:27:03,181 --> 00:27:07,593
Now, what time machine does

00:27:07,593 --> 00:27:12,815
without you having to mess with it too
much and it backs up your data and

505
00:27:12,815 --> 00:27:17,460
what it's doing is it's doing
backups every single hour.

506
00:27:17,460 --> 00:27:20,640
So, once an hour it's trying
to backup your information.

507
00:27:20,640 --> 00:27:24,890
Now, if you have a lot of data,
you might say to yourself, wait,

508
00:27:24,890 --> 00:27:27,930
how does it backup all
of my data once an hour?

509
00:27:27,930 --> 00:27:29,410
And the answer is it doesn't.

510
00:27:29,410 --> 00:27:32,400
What it does is it just
backs up what changed.

511
00:27:32,400 --> 00:27:35,610
The first time machine
backup that you run,

512
00:27:35,610 --> 00:27:40,010
will backup your entire set
of data the whole shebang.

513
00:27:40,010 --> 00:27:43,940
And then every hour after that it
just had to catch what changes.

514
00:27:43,940 --> 00:27:46,350
And that means it can run very, very fast.

515
00:27:46,350 --> 00:27:49,810
It's just getting that changed data,
which is really cool.

516
00:27:49,810 --> 00:27:57,130
And what it'll do, is it'll maintain
an hourly backup, for the last 24 hours.

517
00:27:57,130 --> 00:28:02,545
And then it will maintain a daily
backup for the last 30 days or month.

518
00:28:02,545 --> 00:28:05,389
For the last month or,
well yeah 30 days, whatever.

519
00:28:05,389 --> 00:28:09,690
Some months have 31 days, some have 28,
whatever, but it's for the last month.

520
00:28:09,690 --> 00:28:12,420
So it'll maintain daily backups.

521
00:28:12,420 --> 00:28:17,190
And then it will maintain weekly
backups for the time before that

522
00:28:17,190 --> 00:28:20,445
all the way until you fill up your
Time Machine hard drive, all right.

523
00:28:20,445 --> 00:28:21,860
And you know, eventually,
you run out of space.

524
00:28:21,860 --> 00:28:23,306
You can't save the backups forever.

525
00:28:23,306 --> 00:28:27,320
So, you'll have hourly backups from today.

526
00:28:27,320 --> 00:28:30,400
You'll have daily backups
from the last 30 days.

527
00:28:30,400 --> 00:28:35,070
And then, prior to that, so, last month
and before, we'll have weekly backups,

528
00:28:35,070 --> 00:28:37,800
as far back as we can go,
until we fill up our hard drive.

529
00:28:37,800 --> 00:28:38,420
All right.

530
00:28:38,420 --> 00:28:40,770
So, that's what Time Machine does.

531
00:28:40,770 --> 00:28:44,140
It's running, backing up our data.

532
00:28:44,140 --> 00:28:47,700
If we ever have some kind of a failure,
we can recover our data from there.

533
00:28:47,700 --> 00:28:50,240
Now, what type of failures could we have?

534
00:28:50,240 --> 00:28:52,350
Well, there's the old
classic hard drive failure.

535
00:28:53,500 --> 00:28:57,590
When you have traditional SATA drives,
the Serial ATA drive,

536
00:28:57,590 --> 00:29:00,030
they have spinning
platters inside of them.

537
00:29:00,030 --> 00:29:01,220
They're moving parts.

538
00:29:01,220 --> 00:29:04,820
And if you've got a laptop that
gets jostled around a lot, well,

539
00:29:04,820 --> 00:29:06,260
those drives can get damaged.

540
00:29:06,260 --> 00:29:09,600
Most of those drives are rated for
three years of life anyway.

541
00:29:09,600 --> 00:29:10,860
So even if don't jostle it,

542
00:29:10,860 --> 00:29:15,130
even if you baby your laptop,
after three years, the chance of that

543
00:29:15,130 --> 00:29:19,370
drive failing starts to increase
exponentially as each year goes on.

544
00:29:19,370 --> 00:29:23,050
You'll hear about people who have had hard
drives last for eight years, all right.

545
00:29:23,050 --> 00:29:25,970
But you hear about people who had a hard
drive die in the first year they had it.

546
00:29:25,970 --> 00:29:28,750
It's not a factual thing.

547
00:29:28,750 --> 00:29:31,850
We don't know precisely when
a drive is going to die.

548
00:29:31,850 --> 00:29:35,380
But on average the drives are rated for
three years.

549
00:29:35,380 --> 00:29:38,890
So, after three years you definitely
want to make sure you have that backup.

550
00:29:38,890 --> 00:29:40,310
That drive could fail.

551
00:29:40,310 --> 00:29:44,490
We see the same thing with the new
solid state digital drives, the SSDs.

552
00:29:44,490 --> 00:29:47,910
SSDs have a limit to how many
times you can write to them,

553
00:29:47,910 --> 00:29:51,680
and every time you write data
to them it decreases the life.

554
00:29:51,680 --> 00:29:54,110
Now they're normally rated for
millions of writes, so

555
00:29:54,110 --> 00:29:55,530
you can write to it quite a lot.

556
00:29:55,530 --> 00:29:58,550
But after a few years,
you'll start to hit that limit, and

557
00:29:58,550 --> 00:30:01,750
then the integrity of that drive
starts to drop, all right.

558
00:30:01,750 --> 00:30:06,070
So we had Tim here in the office just a
few weeks ago had this happened, where he

559
00:30:06,070 --> 00:30:11,850

00:30:11,850 --> 00:30:15,840
And it was the one he had his operating
system on, and he couldn't boot up and

00:30:15,840 --> 00:30:17,210
he lost that data.

562
00:30:17,210 --> 00:30:20,460
Well fortunately,
he had Time Machine backups, and

563
00:30:20,460 --> 00:30:22,890
so all he had to do was
get that drive replaced.

564
00:30:22,890 --> 00:30:26,200
It was under warranty, so
he took it down to the Apple store, and

00:30:26,200 --> 00:30:29,630
they replaced the hard drive, and
when Apple replaces the hard drive for

00:30:29,630 --> 00:30:34,515
you, it's already got Mac OS on it,
so he didn't put the hard drive in.

00:30:34,515 --> 00:30:35,355
They put it in for him.

00:30:35,355 --> 00:30:39,235
He just brought it back to the office and

00:30:39,235 --> 00:30:41,305
But it's a clean install, right?

00:30:41,305 --> 00:30:44,940
It's a regular old install that
doesn't have any of his stuff.

571
00:30:44,940 --> 00:30:48,990
And then he was able to fire up Time
Machine, and restore all his data to it.

572
00:30:48,990 --> 00:30:50,790
And it was like he hadn't lost anything.

573
00:30:50,790 --> 00:30:53,130
Time Machine had been
doing backups every hour.

574
00:30:53,130 --> 00:30:54,971
So when he had that failure,

575
00:30:54,971 --> 00:30:58,515
he really at a maximum would

576
00:30:58,515 --> 00:31:01,801
Well fortunately for him, one day ended,
he went home, he came in,

00:31:01,801 --> 00:31:03,740
in the morning, and the drive was dead.

578
00:31:03,740 --> 00:31:07,020
So, it was after an evening
of no changes happening, and

579
00:31:07,020 --> 00:31:09,180
so, he didn't lose any data at all.

580
00:31:09,180 --> 00:31:11,060
And, that's a common scenario.

581
00:31:11,060 --> 00:31:12,860
Now, that's a hardware failure.

00:31:12,860 --> 00:31:16,290
You can also have a people failure too.

00:31:16,290 --> 00:31:18,920
Have you ever accidentally

00:31:18,920 --> 00:31:22,520
Well you know, the recycle bin is kind

But what if you make some changes

So you just saved over the previous

00:31:35,390 --> 00:31:38,470

00:31:38,470 --> 00:31:40,290
Well, the document's not gone.

00:31:40,290 --> 00:31:41,520
The document's not in your trash.

00:31:41,520 --> 00:31:44,715
You just saved over a piece of it,

00:31:44,715 --> 00:31:48,995
With Time Machine, you can see that

00:31:48,995 --> 00:31:51,125

00:31:51,125 --> 00:31:52,889

00:33:17,750 --> 00:33:21,100

00:33:40,370 --> 00:33:43,530

00:33:43,530 --> 00:33:47,060
The other thing is,

Now once we've set our backups, and

892
00:46:52,680 --> 00:46:54,480
we've turned on Time Machine, that's it.

893
00:46:54,480 --> 00:46:55,230
We just walk away.

894
00:46:55,230 --> 00:46:56,100
It's done.
it runs.

895
00:46:56,100 --> 00:46:57,510
It does it's backups.

896
00:46:57,510 --> 00:47:00,350
If you every need to get
data out of it again,

897
00:47:00,350 --> 00:47:03,710
all you have to do is pull down
your Time Machine menu and

898
00:47:03,710 --> 00:47:07,770
you'll see this option right here,
enter Time Machine, all right.

899
00:47:07,770 --> 00:47:10,630
You're entering the Time Machine and
going back in time.

900
00:47:10,630 --> 00:47:15,900
And what it basically does is it
opens up a special Finder window,

901
00:47:15,900 --> 00:47:19,090
and it's gonna, well shoot,
I don't have any backups.

902
00:47:19,090 --> 00:47:22,800
But it's a special Finder window,
basically, that allows you to go through

903
00:47:22,800 --> 00:47:27,600
and search for files, and see all of
the previous versions that were backed up.

904
00:47:27,600 --> 00:47:31,580
You should see, and it's based on changes,
so if the file didn't change today,

905
00:47:31,580 --> 00:47:33,600
you're not gonna see one every hour.

906
00:47:33,600 --> 00:47:36,210
So you'll see the most recent
version in that file and

907
00:47:36,210 --> 00:47:38,750
then the previous changes that
were stored in the backups.

908
00:47:39,910 --> 00:47:43,700
And you can recover the most
recent one if you've got it or

909
00:47:43,700 --> 00:47:47,620
you can recover older ones if
that's what you need to get back to

910
00:47:47,620 --> 00:47:50,160
before the change that
you're trying to undo.

911
00:47:50,160 --> 00:47:51,250
So it's pretty straight forward.

912
00:47:51,250 --> 00:47:53,700
Pretty easy to use, and
you can get at your data.

913
00:47:53,700 --> 00:47:58,130
Now if your computer completely failed,
then you'd be taking your Time Machine

914
00:47:58,130 --> 00:48:01,820
disk and plugging it into
a completely different computer.

915
00:48:01,820 --> 00:48:05,830
And so on that computer,
when you go to enter Time Machine, well,

916
00:48:05,830 --> 00:48:08,100
it's gonna try and
enter its own Time Machine backup.

917
00:48:08,100 --> 00:48:11,780
Since you may need to go into your
Time Machine preferences, and add in that

918
00:48:11,780 --> 00:48:15,610
alternate disk to be able to see it and
pull data out of that, all right.

919
00:48:15,610 --> 00:48:17,010
So just be aware of that.

920
00:48:17,010 --> 00:48:20,140
But otherwise,
Time Machine's pretty straightforward.

921
00:48:20,140 --> 00:48:21,880
This one's gonna churn through and
do its backup, but

922
00:48:21,880 --> 00:48:23,380
I'm not gonna wait for it either.

923
00:48:23,380 --> 00:48:26,820
All right, so
couple of caveats with the network side.

924
00:48:26,820 --> 00:48:31,680
We need to make sure we used AFP, and
the folder needs to be stored on something

925
00:48:31,680 --> 00:48:35,750
that's formatted with the Mac OS
extended journaling file system.

926
00:48:35,750 --> 00:48:38,910
So if we have that, we're good to go.

927
00:48:38,910 --> 00:48:41,460
There is a third option that's
not covered on the exam,

928
00:48:41,460 --> 00:48:43,480
which is when you do your backup,

929
00:48:43,480 --> 00:48:47,900
you can actually back up to systems
that are called time capsules, right?

930
00:48:47,900 --> 00:48:51,410
And these are the ones that are attached
to like our airport wireless devices.

931
00:48:51,410 --> 00:48:54,990
So if you choose to use one of those,
when you hit setup, it's going to launch

932
00:48:54,990 --> 00:48:58,530
the airport utility to try and connect
out and find one of those to backup.

933
00:48:58,530 --> 00:49:00,020
So that's another option.

934
00:49:00,020 --> 00:49:02,950
And then theres always iCloud, you know,
you can synchronize your data with

935
00:49:02,950 --> 00:49:07,880
iCloud as a type of backup, but there are
limits to what you can place into iCloud.

936
00:49:07,880 --> 00:49:10,400
So lots of different options out there.

937
00:49:10,400 --> 00:49:14,050
Time Machine's probably the easiest and
definitely a good one.

938
00:49:15,590 --> 00:49:16,096
All right.

939
00:49:16,096 --> 00:49:18,700
So that's about it for
data management and back-up.

940
00:49:18,700 --> 00:49:20,550
I don't think I'm leaving
anything else out.

941
00:49:20,550 --> 00:49:24,460
Let me just double check real quick,
and yeah, that's about it.

942
00:49:24,460 --> 00:49:28,210
All right, so that's about all we've got
on time machine and on migrating our data,

943
00:49:28,210 --> 00:49:32,310
so pretty straight forward, should be
a pretty easy section for you on the exam.

944
00:49:32,310 --> 00:49:35,260
All right well, we're gonna wrap this
episode up here, so let me just remind you

945
00:49:35,260 --> 00:49:39,800
guys, if you have any questions
on any of this, feel free to ask.

946
00:49:39,800 --> 00:49:42,490
Live during the show,
you can go to itpro.tv/live, and

947
00:49:42,490 --> 00:49:45,140
you'll see the chat box
right beneath the video.

948
00:49:45,140 --> 00:49:48,710
You can post your questions there, and we
answer and sometimes we shoot the breeze.

949
00:49:48,710 --> 00:49:52,290
We were talking about expensive
cable costs during the break.

950
00:49:52,290 --> 00:49:54,380
So there's the various things there.

951
00:49:54,380 --> 00:49:58,490
If you have questions after the show,
jump into our Q and A forums.

952
00:49:58,490 --> 00:50:00,920
If you hit that Q and
A link up at the top of the page,

953
00:50:00,920 --> 00:50:03,270
it'll take you into the forums, and
you can ask your questions there.

954
00:50:03,270 --> 00:50:04,780
And again, we monitor and answer.

955
00:50:04,780 --> 00:50:06,660
So take advantage of those resources.

956
00:50:06,660 --> 00:50:08,940
They are there for you.

957
00:50:08,940 --> 00:50:12,678
All right.
Well, I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

958
00:50:12,678 --> 00:50:21,040
Signing off fro IT PRO TV,

959
00:50:28,130 --> 00:50:31,840
I'm Don Pezet, and I'll see you next time.

episodes.description: Cross-platform compatibility refers to the ability of certain software or applications to operate across multiple platforms as opposed to only one. Viewers will hear about how to virtualize a Windows environment on a Mac, how Boot Camp works to create a dual bootable system, and the steps in getting Boot Camp set up.
episodes.title: Cross-Platform Compatibility
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,754 --> 00:00:36,341
All right, good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening, and welcome back.

3
00:00:37,350 --> 00:00:38,840
To another episode of IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:38,840 --> 00:00:40,920
I'm your host Don Pezet,

5
00:00:40,920 --> 00:00:45,220
coming back at you with another
episode of Mac integration basics.

6
00:00:45,220 --> 00:00:47,630
Not just another episode,

7
00:00:47,630 --> 00:00:51,720
As we move into our last topic for
the exam objectives, and

8
00:00:51,720 --> 00:00:55,110
that is cross platform compatibility.

9
00:00:55,110 --> 00:00:59,410
That's a really long way of saying
man I just moved over from Windows,

10
00:00:59,410 --> 00:01:02,340
now I'm on a Mac but
there's some software that I miss.

11
00:01:03,430 --> 00:01:07,950
For a home user, moving from Windows
to Mac is really not a big deal right?

12
00:01:07,950 --> 00:01:11,110
Your average home user needs
web browsing capabilities and

13
00:01:11,110 --> 00:01:14,286
some basic file sharing and
that kind of stuff, nothing too crazy.

14
00:01:14,286 --> 00:01:19,130
And your Mac will do that, so there's
not much of a hindrance there at all for

15
00:01:19,130 --> 00:01:21,830
a home user to jump from
one platform to another.

16
00:01:21,830 --> 00:01:24,430
But in the business world
it's a different story.

17
00:01:24,430 --> 00:01:25,370
In the business world,

18
00:01:25,370 --> 00:01:29,190
if there's a developer out there
writing a line of business application,

19
00:01:29,190 --> 00:01:33,120
they're gonna write it for the platform
that has the biggest install base.

20
00:01:33,120 --> 00:01:36,010
And in the business world
that's Microsoft Windows.

21
00:01:36,010 --> 00:01:39,630
So there are many applications that
are available on the Windows platform

22
00:01:39,630 --> 00:01:42,410
that are not available
on the Mac platform.

23
00:01:42,410 --> 00:01:46,350
And so making that switch in the business
world can be very challenging, all right.

24
00:01:46,350 --> 00:01:47,600
So what do we do?

25
00:01:47,600 --> 00:01:50,340
Do we just give up and
say alright we'll run Windows forever?

26
00:01:50,340 --> 00:01:51,690
No, we don't have to do that.

27
00:01:51,690 --> 00:01:55,070
There's several different routes
we can go to get it where

28
00:01:55,070 --> 00:01:59,090
we can still take advantage of that
software, even on the Mac platform.

29
00:01:59,090 --> 00:02:05,220
Now obviously, the best case scenario is,
if I had software on the Windows side,

30
00:02:05,220 --> 00:02:08,560
hopefully they make that same software
on the Mac side, and more and

31
00:02:08,560 --> 00:02:11,770
more we're seeing that where
companies make it for both.

32
00:02:11,770 --> 00:02:16,160
So, let's say you really like
the Google Chrome web browser.

33
00:02:17,160 --> 00:02:21,320
Well, google chrome came out
on Microsoft Windows first.

34
00:02:21,320 --> 00:02:23,680
That was the first platform
they released it for.

35
00:02:23,680 --> 00:02:26,470
Then they released it for
Linux and Mac OS.

36
00:02:26,470 --> 00:02:29,450
So it did come out on Mac OS and
it's been out for years now.

37
00:02:29,450 --> 00:02:30,670
Very, very popular.

38
00:02:30,670 --> 00:02:37,750
So when I switch from Windows to Mac,
I just download the Mac version of Chrome.

39
00:02:37,750 --> 00:02:40,568
And it can be even more complex
applications than that.

40
00:02:40,568 --> 00:02:45,320
Applications like Quicken,
into it Quicken.

41
00:02:45,320 --> 00:02:47,430
Or Microsoft Office.

42
00:02:47,430 --> 00:02:48,770
The entire Office suite.

43
00:02:48,770 --> 00:02:50,290
Microsoft has a Mac version.

44
00:02:50,290 --> 00:02:52,050
I've got their website
pulled up right here.

45
00:02:52,050 --> 00:02:55,800
So, maybe you're used to
Microsoft Word and Microsoft Excel.

46
00:02:55,800 --> 00:03:01,420
Well, we have the numbers and
applications like that on the Mac side.

47
00:03:01,420 --> 00:03:04,030
We have iWork and
all that that we could use.

48
00:03:04,030 --> 00:03:06,550
Or we can just get Microsoft Office for
Mac.

49
00:03:06,550 --> 00:03:10,080
It's Excel, Word, PowerPoint,
Outlooks and One Note.

50
00:03:10,080 --> 00:03:13,960
The same applications you run on Windows,
you run them on a Mac, right?

51
00:03:13,960 --> 00:03:15,340
So now that learning curve.

52
00:03:15,340 --> 00:03:18,080
That resistance to jumping over
to the new platform is gone,

53
00:03:18,080 --> 00:03:20,780
because it's the same
application that you're used to.

54
00:03:20,780 --> 00:03:22,350
That's really the best solution.

55
00:03:22,350 --> 00:03:27,240
If you can do that If you can
get a native Mac OS application

56
00:03:27,240 --> 00:03:30,090
that matches the application
you have under Windows.

57
00:03:30,090 --> 00:03:33,720
Then you get zero resistance from
the users, very smooth transition, and

58
00:03:33,720 --> 00:03:34,320
off you go.

59
00:03:34,320 --> 00:03:37,230
And like I said, more and
more we're starting to see that.

60
00:03:37,230 --> 00:03:42,330
But sometimes there are applications
that don't run on both platforms.

61
00:03:42,330 --> 00:03:43,600
So for example,

62
00:03:43,600 --> 00:03:49,096
one of my favorite Windows applications
is a program called Notepad++.

63
00:03:49,096 --> 00:03:52,380
Notepad++, it's a simple text editor.

64
00:03:52,380 --> 00:03:57,550
And There are many text editors available
on the Mac side, but not this one.

65
00:03:57,550 --> 00:04:00,100
Notepad ++ doesn't have a Mac version.

66
00:04:00,100 --> 00:04:04,120
And on the Mac side the closest ones match

67
00:04:04,120 --> 00:04:09,290
this cost like $80, $90, but
this is completely free so

68
00:04:09,290 --> 00:04:12,330
I really like this solution, but
it's not available on the Mac.

69
00:04:12,330 --> 00:04:13,250
So what do I do?

70
00:04:13,250 --> 00:04:16,110
Well, you've got a few choices there too.

71
00:04:16,110 --> 00:04:18,570
One, you could find an alternative,

72
00:04:18,570 --> 00:04:22,100
some other kind of software that
matches up with what you want.

73
00:04:22,100 --> 00:04:25,580
So, you might talk to some people and
say, hey what do you guys use for

74
00:04:25,580 --> 00:04:26,300
a text editor?

75
00:04:26,300 --> 00:04:28,440
You could search the App store.

76
00:04:28,440 --> 00:04:30,385
I like this website called alternativeTo.

77
00:04:30,385 --> 00:04:34,920
AlternativeTo.net, you go there and
you punch in the software that you use.

78
00:04:34,920 --> 00:04:37,348
So I'm gonna say Notepad++, all right?

79
00:04:37,348 --> 00:04:39,660
I use Notepad++ and I like it.

80
00:04:39,660 --> 00:04:41,580
So here it is, Notepad++.

81
00:04:41,580 --> 00:04:44,880
And then down here it's
gonna show me alternatives,

82
00:04:44,880 --> 00:04:46,600
other programs that match up.

83
00:04:46,600 --> 00:04:48,710
And so I can change that to say,
you know what?

84
00:04:48,710 --> 00:04:52,530
Just show me Mac OS X or OS10 apps.

85
00:04:52,530 --> 00:04:56,920
And it's gonna recommend Sublime Text,
or Vim, gedit, Aptana,

86
00:04:56,920 --> 00:04:58,500
all these different ones, all right?

87
00:04:58,500 --> 00:05:01,370
Wow, kind of down the list is TextMate,
that's the one that I use.

88
00:05:01,370 --> 00:05:04,080
So you'll see like when I have
my show notes up on the screen,

89
00:05:04,080 --> 00:05:06,100
I almost always use TextMate.

90
00:05:06,100 --> 00:05:09,050
Which I find gives me
everything that Notepad++ did,

91
00:05:09,050 --> 00:05:10,910
so that's the one that I use.

92
00:05:10,910 --> 00:05:14,330
But here's how we can start to see
what other people are voting for.

93
00:05:14,330 --> 00:05:17,980
Sublime Text has 609 votes, so
that's a pretty good one, right?

94
00:05:17,980 --> 00:05:22,190
So we can go and look at that and see if
that's gonna be a good alternative for us.

95
00:05:22,190 --> 00:05:25,550
And maybe Sublime Text is the choice for
me.

96
00:05:25,550 --> 00:05:27,060
So we can find that.

97
00:05:27,060 --> 00:05:29,490
Now we have to relearn
some software though.

98
00:05:29,490 --> 00:05:31,080
And so you'll get resistance on this.

99
00:05:31,080 --> 00:05:33,870
You'll get where people say,
well I don't want to learn new software,

100
00:05:33,870 --> 00:05:36,850
I was happy with what I had,
maybe I'll just stay on Windows.

101
00:05:36,850 --> 00:05:37,520
If you can't,

102
00:05:37,520 --> 00:05:42,049
you know, run my program over on your Mac,
then I'll just stick with Windows.

103
00:05:43,660 --> 00:05:46,320
Or there may not be an alternative.

104
00:05:46,320 --> 00:05:50,620
You may have a custom application
that was written specifically for

105
00:05:50,620 --> 00:05:53,670
your business and
it was only written for Windows.

106
00:05:53,670 --> 00:05:55,360
And so, there is no alternative.

107
00:05:55,360 --> 00:06:00,550
That was a custom application and
to pay a developer to rewrite it as

108
00:06:00,550 --> 00:06:06,240
a native Mac app, might be prohibitively
expensive, just outrageously expensive.

109
00:06:06,240 --> 00:06:08,380
So, do you just stay on Windows?

110
00:06:08,380 --> 00:06:10,290
Well, you could, right?

111
00:06:10,290 --> 00:06:15,650
Or you could go ahead and switch over
to Mac and use virtualization software,

112
00:06:15,650 --> 00:06:19,700
to virtualize a Windows environment
right on top of your Mac.

113
00:06:19,700 --> 00:06:21,670
There's several programs that
are out there that do it,

114
00:06:23,090 --> 00:06:27,010
the two main leaders in it
are Parallels and VMWare.

115
00:06:27,010 --> 00:06:27,590
All right.

116
00:06:27,590 --> 00:06:31,860
Parallels is a company that makes a
product called Parallels Desktop for Mac.

117
00:06:31,860 --> 00:06:35,270
You install it on your Mac and
it allows you to run Windows,

118
00:06:35,270 --> 00:06:37,540
as a virtual machine, on top of your Mac.

119
00:06:39,030 --> 00:06:41,920
VMware has a product called VMware Fusion,
and

120
00:06:41,920 --> 00:06:44,780
it allows you to run Windows on your Mac.

121
00:06:44,780 --> 00:06:49,430
It's the same thing, so
you're running your Mac OS, and

122
00:06:49,430 --> 00:06:51,760
then you have a Windows
operating system on top of it.

123
00:06:51,760 --> 00:06:55,850
And I've actually been using
VMware Fusion all throughout this show.

124
00:06:55,850 --> 00:06:59,423
Every time I've brought up a Mac client or
a Windows client or whatever,

125
00:06:59,423 --> 00:07:02,100
it's been in my VMWARE Fusion environment.

126
00:07:02,100 --> 00:07:03,940
So let me show you that one.

127
00:07:03,940 --> 00:07:07,470
Because I have been running it all show,
but I hide it.

128
00:07:07,470 --> 00:07:10,210
So here is VMware Fusion.

129
00:07:10,210 --> 00:07:12,910
And you can see my virtual machines,
I had others,

130
00:07:12,910 --> 00:07:14,960
I've removed them as the show has gone on.

131
00:07:14,960 --> 00:07:17,190
But I've got a Windows client,
that's running Windows 7,

132
00:07:17,190 --> 00:07:20,100
and it's kind of parked
here in the background.

133
00:07:20,100 --> 00:07:24,560
And if I pull it up, here it is,
and I'm still on my Mac, right?

134
00:07:24,560 --> 00:07:28,100
So I can fire up my app store, right here.

135
00:07:28,100 --> 00:07:31,740
And I can browse in and
take a look at stuff, shop for

136
00:07:31,740 --> 00:07:34,590
the latest angry birds game,
whatever it is I'm gonna do.

137
00:07:34,590 --> 00:07:38,340
And meanwhile I've got this Windows
7 desk top sitting right here.

138
00:07:38,340 --> 00:07:45,768
And I can fire it up and I can go
to the internet and find Notepad++.

139
00:07:45,768 --> 00:07:48,628
There we go.

140
00:07:48,628 --> 00:07:52,298
And so I can go in and install it and
run Notepad++ just like I used to.

141
00:07:52,298 --> 00:07:52,958
Okay?

142
00:07:52,958 --> 00:07:57,960
Now, on a positive side,
you can run any Windows software this way.

143
00:07:57,960 --> 00:08:02,010
So I can run my Windows software
right here in the virtual machine.

144
00:08:02,010 --> 00:08:05,990
On a negative side,
it's not the greatest user experience.

145
00:08:05,990 --> 00:08:09,440
Your end user now has two machines.

146
00:08:09,440 --> 00:08:12,870
They've got their Mac and they've
got this Windows virtual machine and

147
00:08:12,870 --> 00:08:14,520
they're kind of going back and forth.

148
00:08:14,520 --> 00:08:19,200
And if they use this application a lot,
what you'll find they end up doing

149
00:08:19,200 --> 00:08:22,460
is they'll full screen this
virtual machine, right?

150
00:08:22,460 --> 00:08:26,630
So if I take it and
I full-screen it like this, so

151
00:08:26,630 --> 00:08:31,280
if they're always running the Windows
machine, they may full screen it and

152
00:08:31,280 --> 00:08:34,550
start working in it and
never go to the Mac desk top.

153
00:08:34,550 --> 00:08:37,360
And so now, why bother going to a Mac?

154
00:08:37,360 --> 00:08:38,768
You might as well just stuck with the PC.

155
00:08:38,768 --> 00:08:42,230
If they're gonna run right here in
their Windows environment all the time,

156
00:08:42,230 --> 00:08:46,360
you lose all the benefits
of going the Mac route.

157
